Another day, another live viewing of bombs dropping on Iraq. Incidentally, my computer started playing B.O.B. by Outkast 5 minutes into my military vouyerism . . . weird How is one supposed to act in a time of war? Especially when we have no control over it? I have no clue how I feel on it, on one hand I have no wish to see the States subjected to a nuclear or biological weapon's attack and on the other I have no wish to see innocent people lose their lives . . . . . arrrrrgh! Stupid grey areas! As a politics student, I find the United States is acting the way it needs to act. Just stay with me here, I don't condone what they are doing at all, but I understand. In realpolitik the USA is doing what it needs to do to maintain its favoured position in the global arena. If it were to act "nice" and not pursue what is in its interests then there would be anarchy in their home country. The citizens of the United States would reach for their guns (which they are entitled to do . . . I'm not gonna get started on that one) if there was ever a substantial drop in the quality of life that they have been accustomed. Providing meaningful help to other nations that wouldn't doom them as economic vassals of America would reduce the United States quality of life and in a way, the American politicans would be failing their citizens by not providing them with the best possible life. They are elected to better Americans, not other nations. The international framework is called an arena for a purpose. It implies competition. Humanity is winners and losers and if I think about it anymore I get depressed. I can't believe how lucky I am to live in Canada. It was co-incidence that I was born to the parents that I was and in the area that I was. I could of been an Albanian in Kosovo, I could have been born in a Nairobi gutter. No wonder I identify with existentialism so much. it breaks my heart to realise this. If anyone out there has a different opinion please please please tell me. Email me if you want to tell me how wrong I am - I need another opinion because this view just scares me and makes me more cynical. blargh ajc

www.ootp5.com this game has taken over my life It is the perfect way to procrastinate. Speaking of procrastination, I was able to write a 15 page paper on "The Internet and its effects on Mass Media" in about four hours. 3500 words 4 hours The only thing that school has taught me is how to work the system for maximum benefit. I spent one evening (6 hours in total) grabbing about 14 journal articles off the web and then reading them, and tghen cutting and pasting the relevant information onto a blank Word document. That was all the research I needed. The four hours of the actual paper writing process went like this: I first went through the fifteen pages of cut-and-paste web notes and put them into order on to another document so that they could form relevant paragraphs (footnoting all the time so that I'm not kicked out of school for plagirism). This took about an hour and garnered me about nine and a half pages of "written" work. Then I began writing my introduction which took 10 minutes and brought the page count to 10 and a half (I never make my intro less than a page in length - it's just uncivilized). Then it took me another three hours to write five pages of my own work, rewrite a bunch of the direct cut and pasted material (while still citing it) and putting together up my bibliography. This was worth forty percent of my mark What is the lesson here? University is a joke. I don't go to class, I drink like a fish, I play video games, I play guitar in a band and haven't given a fuck about my education since I was accepted to this university in 1998. I have given this place every opportunity to fail me but they keep giving me marks in the 70s despite the effort that would make my mother weep if she knew Case in point: Last year I had a 12 page English essay due on the Monday of Reading Week and I was leaving for Boca Raton ("Boca Baby! Boca!") on the Sunday. Damned if I was going to work on that thing. So on the Friday night I borrowed a friend's laptop and went to the Queen's Pub (a bar on campus) and proceeded to drink, flirt with a girl who would become my girlfriend after Reading week, and write my essay. All in that order. I handed in the worst example of writing since Mein Kampf Final grade: 82% Thank you gifted high school education for teaching me how to write what professors want to read. Such exceptional skills they have imparted upon me. blargh ajc

You didn't leave with anyone (yeah - I checked, I'm a dumb male) I left with her; does that mean I win? Is there a winning and why do I care about it? Then the two of you fumble through the emotional crap for the first time in your lives and then the selfishness takes over, and you get out before you get hurt and hurt them in the process. My last Sunday night at the hotel. My last night at the hotel. The housekeeping ladies threw me a small party with a cake. I had no idea I was so loved . . . as a group they hate the hotel management and I habve never really bothered to hide my contempt for the owners of this place, and as such, they have always appreciated my barbs towards the higher ups. mad props were thrown all 'round . . . in an almost haphazard, willy-nilly fashion now there is less than two hours left in my sentence and I can go back to enjoying my Sunday nights . . . . I have an entire season of Simpsons to catch up on now. Then, Graduation. I'm not too sad, but it will hit me when I'm in Toronto and lonely - not so much for the individual people that I'm leaving behind here at Queen's, but for the lifestyle that I have experienced as a 19 to 24 year old. For instance: last Tuesday, Bob (my housemate) and I threw a kegger. Bob bought a keg of Keith's and refused to charge admission for it. Free Beer. (Bob works three jobs, two of which are merely titles right now, but he gets paid quite well - it's a long story involving our third housemate who moved out in December and far too boring for this piece of the Internet) Anyway, the beer was just Bob's way of having a good time. And a good time was had!!!! We had a ton of people over and drank about a third of the keg (we had a further get together Friday night for hockey and partially-flat Keith's) and anyone there could not have cared less about the next day. I played an acoustic set of music with my lead singer in the living room and was in heaven for an evening. It's evenings of the like that I will miss when I'm stuck at home in my parent's house in June. The Complete and Utter Lack of Responsibility. Friends who live - at maximum - ten minutes away and we only need a designated driver if we're going to steal shopping carts from the A&P across the street. Strangers that become formal dates that become 'sleepover friends' all in the span of an evening. Walkinbg up to a friend's door unannounced and knowing that a) the door will be unlocked b) you're always welcome c) it's 3 a.m. on a Tuesday and all their lights are on. I can't really describe what it has been like going to school here at Queen's, but it really is it's own self-contained community. It gets knocked for that reason yet I have loved just about every moment (well, barring a month here and there) that I've been able to spend at it. It really is a world unto itself and I've been lucky enough to take advantage of so many opportunities that it has thrown my way. I'm happy I'm here. I'm happy to have been here. I'm going to miss the atmosphere. Just about anything could happen on any given day. blargh ajc

I'm sorry for the infrequency of my posts. The main reason has been that I just haven't had a lot to say about anything much at all. That being said, I have arranged my exit away from my childhood home and a relocation to the pristine wilderness of Colebrook New Hampshire. I like the fact that I accepted a job in the United States on Canada Day. Last thursday I woke up at 4 am to board a 6:30 flight to Manchester NH via 3-hour layover in Detroit. An uneventful journey landed me in the middle of an airport that felt like Winnipeg's (small, compact and sweltering) with a vague sense of apprehension. Random thought to myself: "What the hell am I doing here?" It was all gravy from there. I was met at the airport by an elderly gentleman who worked for Eckerd named Tom and we drove for three hours up to the camp. The scenery was breathtaking. It really was. In a good news moment, I found out that New Hampshire is the second lowest state in terms of the level of taxes that it imposes upon its population. Translation: there is no state income tax nor is there a state sales tax. The price is see is the price you pay. I am going to save a bundle of money from this job. Not only that, but the camp provides me with five pairs of pants and five t-shirts a well as winter gear and a whole whack of other perks that I am just scratching the surface of. The kicker? When I first arrived in camp I gazed around at the surroundings and noticed a small area that was enclosed that looked from a distance like large animal pen with solid wood walls. I inquired as to whether they took care of animals and Tom looked at me as if I had overdosed on a healthy handful of goofballs. Apparently what I thought was a farm pen from a distance was in fact a REGULATION OUTDOOR HOCKEY RINK. They play hockey outdoors (and the camp has a full set of gear for two teams - goalies included) from November until the snow leaves. It almost made this Canadian kid cry. Needless to say, I had a phenomenal four days up in the wilderness. They offered me a job and I took it. I am off to begin a two year contract on the 16th of July. I have new boots from M.E.C., a smile on my face and a new way to fill in application forms. Instead of being a 'student', I am now a 'theaputic worker' and a soon-to-be-Canadian-ex-patriate. I can't wait to begin. I hate being here in the city and feeling like I don't belong in this town. I am far too comfortable with the freedom that I had in Kingston and I don't feel it here. Toronto doesn't want me, not in a malicious way, it just has too many other things to be concerned with and I can' be bothered to clamour for its attention. The smog gets in my eyes and makes me turn away to clear my senses. There was a community at Queen's of the like-minded in cahoots against something else. A secret joke that permeated the campus and those around it. I like the community at Eckerd. It's small and warm - it needs to be, the winters get to thirty below - and besides, I can finally get rid of my caffeine habit. I'll miss a lot of new music, but I can get back to it when I need to. Hell I think it's starting to be of lesser importance in my life. . . . . . . . . but let's not get carried away. Music will always be there in my life. The weather will suck and the kids will abuse me. They really will, I haven't met one counselor yet who doesn't have a story about a child attacking them, but what do I care. I was worried that I'd be a young'un in terms of the staff but my age (24) is right on the median for starting counselors (Thank you OAC and victory lap!). In early August I'll travel down to either Florida or North Carolina for a three week training course in the wilderness there. The best news: They allow long hair and beards! I have always wanted to see what I'd look like with both or either of these states of appearance and this job will let me do it. My plan is to buzz my hair pretty short for the summer and then start the growth process . . . . I should have a pretty healthy white man's afro by Christmas, so when I get back to T.O. in December you can all go clubbing with me and my Funk Soul Brother hair. The beard growth begins immediately upon arrival. I hate shaving. I really really do. That was one of my biggest (albeit wussiest) complaints about working at the Hojo. I had to shave everytime I went to work. It was such a hassle. So I'll give up my dreams of a bohemian cosmopolitan lifestyle here in Canada's largest city for a chance to "get in touch with [my] inner redneck". I'm dropping out of society for a while but I can make it to Montreal on my weekends and I'll be in KIngston for Homecoming. I have to be. I just have to be. I'll have money. There's thirsty undergraduate (and graduate, Hi Geobey!) friends of mine who need free alcohol that only a freshly graduated and employed compatriate can provide them with. Plus, I can help soften the brain drain by dropping a healthy wad of American cash at Clark Hall, QP and Alfies. Oh the plans that I am formulating. I haven't been this excited in a while. New Hampshire the State has one quarter of Toronto the City's population. I heard a voice calling from the wilderness. Calling from the Wilderness. Not quite a whistle. Not quite a song. Not too short. Not long. - Martin Tielli why are the Rheostatics so damnned good? why? blargh ajc

So this is the New Year . . . . and I don't feel any different Well, I would like to astound you all with new and exciting stories of daring do that have occurred up at Camp E-Toh-Anee over the past two months but I can't. Then, the New Hampshire government decides to cut 2 million from its social services budget. This meant that we could only afford three groups on property soooooooooooo goodbye Sunapees! They shipped the worst kids out and split the rest between the remaining three groups. Happy day! I was going to get a group switch! Huzzah! Life will no longer be shitty. I'll have kids that will want to work on their issues and change as opposed to little fuckheads that want to cause shit and make everyone's lives miserable. That was my thought process. Unfortunately, I was placed into the Ammonosucs (Ammos for short) and promptly the group began to fall apart. Placed on top of this is the fact that our new Program Director is trying to make my new co-chief and I be more physical with the kids. Restrain them more instead of talking to them. It's a long discussion that can be noiled down to in this way: My co-counselor and I get shit on weekly due to the fact that the group is runnuing badly. The kids don;t get to bed until at least 10 pm nightly and since I've been back I haven't had a day when I haven't ahd to hold onto a kid. I think that I am not suited for this job/lifestlye. I'm tired of having to grab a kid and wrestle with them. I want to be able to deal with real issues without having one of my kids throw a stupid, petty problem. Example: On Sunday night one of my guys decided to lwet group know that he had been sexual abused twice by a cop when he was growing up - one of the most couragous things I've ever seen and one of the heaviest moments that I have ever had to deal with. He had told me a few hours before and had been crying on my shoulder (and I was crying right back). For the most part the group did very well and gave the guy a ton of support and encouragement. Thirty minutes later all hell had broken loose. I had my arm slammed in a door, had to pull two kids off of another, and had to grab on to two different guys running around campsite. I am getting tired of this shit. I really am. It sucks having to grab a hold of a guy. It sucks having to wake up thinking "Oh shit, who am I going to deal with today?" It sucks wondering what part of me is going to get hurt today. I've had so many different injuries occur doe to the kids that it is just wearing me down. Added on to that is the fact that I am far away from the wonders of modern living and I hardly get any time to communicate with friends and family - who I dearly miss. So, I'll probably be out of this job either as early as May or as late as August. But who knows . . . things might get better and I'll wind up staying. It's hard to admit when you can't do something that you want to but I think I am getting close to that stage. If I do leave I'll probably go back to Toronto and try to find temporary work as a hotel clerk while looking for something permanent - if anything just to be able to make my car payments/ car insurance payments monthly. I think I'll take urlLink Karen's advice and carry a horse pendant in my pocket. My luck's gotta change sometime . . . . . blargh ajc

No one has yet to figure out the lock, by yet the door is always open and the line is indefatigable in its enormity - look at the fences meant to constrain it. Look at the words that contain it and keep it from boiling over, albeit without any hope of success. It is a country meant to boil over on to itself, seething and burning, but nothing cleanses better than fire. Thats why Nature burns forests. America is a Constitution but was brought in to this world shouting at the top of its lungs clamouring for attention. It did not end its first sentence with a period but with an exclamation for its Declaration! It is the worlds Modern Democracy. Forget Europe. Forget Asia. Forget Africa. This is it baby! All thrown together with the hating, the bile, the suffering and the imagined idea that yesterdays cotton slave is tomorrows SUV owner. This is the land of Equal and other artificial flavours. It is the land of promises that may be empty, but at least we are given a cup and told: Fill it up boys! Fill it up girls! I dont care what your groin contains! Fill to the brim and if it overflows, Build Another! Build The Biggest One You Can Until It Cracks Under Your Weight! In the history of the Rest of The Word these promises are made, but not with the urgency and the level of earnestness that comes with the voices that trumpet it. Greece: the germ of the idea, then vaccinated by class and other such educational devices that the Romans juryrigged, be it originated by the Caesars or the Charlemagnes. Where the feud was with the feudal system and the lies brought out with their own crosses to bear. A light quickly snuffed out by the Dark Ages. But oh what a light! The seed in need of a new ground. Europe: a whitewash of masqueraded intolerance and the only land where Hate is a Final Solution on a plain round the Cape of Good Hope. The Germans were kept in first and they adopted the stiff upper lip. The only Good Indian was a Dead Indian no matter the continent, no matter the god. This is a continent that prints incorrect maps to make itself look bigger. Where nationalism was devised only to legally divide Warring Tribes still at each others throats. Britain: oh so much of the pomp, but the circumstances vary with names. In America, Lord is a surname at best while England kindly places all of them in one House where they may shout at each other as to where they shall vacation. The United Kingdom is the closest of the Old World to the New, but can only be the sad pathetic dad, aping his childs behaviour to gain the acceptance so desperately needed. Where the promise was given to get men to quench their fires and drop their pitchforks. Democracy makes a horrible release value for the steam of class anger. America gave the promise and then continued on, extolling her protgs: Make your own fire. Build your own pitchfork.Sell it to the highest bidder! Theres land for us all! Theres hope for us all! Britain saw that these were weapons. America saw that these were tools. What trust! It is here that the experiment of Trust was undertaken. The trust in the Brain, the trust in the Brawn, and the trust that we can all sort it out together, no matter if Brain is masquerading as Brawn. Many were given that trust a million times more had to fight for it. It was a simple trust, one set forth by imperfect men and then captured by women and those once seen as half a man. They fought for it at Bull Run, at Shiloh, in Hells Kitchen, in Brooklyn. Freedom kept on marching in Alabama, in Chicago and in every other undocumented battlefield. The Brain and the Brawn, at war with each other over the ground of the heart. The Hate that consumes no matter what the date, time or place. Authors and victors, every one of them human, and all of them flawed imperfections of their ancestors. The nation reflecting the limitations but resounding with the call of Hope: a fire that is Abel to Hates Cain. A fire that is able to remain burning here, in the last outpost of humanity, all the while seeking to illuminate Americas tabla rasa. Hope, Trust, and the Tools to see it forward. That is our gift. The Hate will remain. The world has seen so much Hate. Proof? You can glance at the history books where the words jump out at your eyes: Mongols, Christians, Saracens, Protestants, Balkans. Or one could take a jet over to the dividing line of Palestine. You can stroll through Compton or Rexdale and Ill pay you for each white face we see. The ghettos of Warsaw can be glimpsed in the projects of Chicago. One Age is not a finality. Everything changes, evolves and metaphorizes. America can take its jazzercise, taebo and transform it because of the tools. You cant pass each test without lessons. You cant advance each grade without age. America is the student with Nature as its teacher. Humanitys the Class Clown. Nature cries out: Learn the lesson or repeat the grade until you get it right! Horrible, despicable, yet all necessary so as not to repeat it. Freedom: Barking and yelping at the table then hit on the nose when it begged for scraps. Kicked in the ribs, but then back to fetch the masters slippers. It has been given the breath of life and cant be undone. No alteration can be learned without evolution. Now is not a final end, hell it isnt even close. It is a limitless chain stretching to the future with an anchor to the Promises of the Past, put into each mind with each new school day. We continue to create the unknowing lessons so that they may learn. We are only 130 years removed from a war to make the blacks people and one generation removed from making them People. We are the first colourblind generation and we are in transition we are a living classroom for those down the line. And when it falls down, who are you going to call now? Hate was the birthstone of America and it sparkles in the fire of every violent act. It is the heat of the forge and the heat of the anvil upon which the Future is Being Wrought. A Haven that brings together the Others, but gives them the Tools and the Promise so that one day Hope will be replaced with Now and they will intertwine and create something wonderful. Amen. What the hell do I know anyway?

A Good Weekend Means A Crappy Monday There was tons of goodness from Thursday on. Tons. A baseball game was taken in on the Thursday night. Of course, when you put together an infield of Chris Gomez at third, Chris Woodward at short, Frank Menechino at second (and leadoff! ), along with special guest star Dave "Double A" Berg at first, you have only yourself to blame. Unfortunately we almost got caught as we were filling up in the top row - an usher snuck up on us to give us All Star ballots. Well, there wasn't so much stealth involved in as much as our half-assed attempt to hide the bottle. So, presumably while the usher went to get reinforcements we quickly emptied the contents of the bottle into our drinks and hightailed to the opposite end of the stadium - where we spent 15 minutes filling out All Star ballots with Dave Berg's name. Hey, why not? The game was good, and so was drinking afterwards. Work Friday went by in a blur. I did as little work as possible in as much time as possible. Wheeeeeee. Friday night Brent, his girlfriend Jess and I met up at Dave's condo, and we promptly drank a lot. We drank White Russians on the condo's communal rooftop patio and shuffled off to My Apartment where we met up with Wee Kirsty and Evan. A good time was had despite the sardine nature of the club. "Bite the dog that bit you" is one of Chris Bittle's favourite sayings, and it proved true in this case. I haven't been this hungover in a while. It wasn't until later that I realised that it wasn't the beer that did it to me, but it was the shots that I had forgotten about . . . . . So Dave, Kirsty and I made breakfast and ate it up on the roof in glorious sunshine with an increadible view. It was a great morning. The nap later was even better. We had a great dinner and an even better time at the Madison, where we ran in to urlLink Eric and Laura. Now I am sitting here at work, way too tired from the festivities of the weekend to really care about the crappy things I have to do here. Not only that but there's a Subaru sitting forlornly in my garage like a prisoner on death row, waiting for its future to be decided. I don't want to sell it, but it looks like I have to. Crap. ajc

I'm sorry . . . I normally hate politics I try to stay out of politics, mostly due to the fact that I consider myself not that well informed and also I got sick of it after 5 years at Queen's. That being said, I don't think that anyone can in good conscience vote for Stephen Harper, or allow him to become Prime Minister. I believe that Canada's recent increasingly liberal attitudes, especially those towards gay marriage, are a positive change for the country. I believe that we should not being moving towards becoming more like the American government both in our tax system and in our medical system. Harper, from what I have read and understand, is a proponent of our neighbours to the south and wants this country to move closer to the United States. He would have sent our troops to the ill-conceived war in Iraq. He would in all probability endorse a two tier health care system and make bad decisions for this country. The economic plan concocted by his party makes no sense and does not add up. I also cannot stand the man. Now the Liberals are no saints. Their infighting, egos and nepotism prevented them from fully taking advantage of their years in office. Well, they took advantage alright . . . . . The Liberals were greedy, duplicitous, and prone to scandal. Who knows what they'll do in office again? Where the hell does that leave us? I can't vote NDP. I would like to but it is my belief that voting for a candidate that has no chance of winning simply as a way of protest does not work. It is also my belief that people using this way of thinking and voting for Ralph Nader in the last U.S. presidential election helped to give the White House to the least effective president since Coolidge. I get the same goose bumps about Harper that I have about Bush Jr. That being said, it is my hope that there is a minority Liberal government, with the balance of power being held by the NDP. That way Harper can be prevented from having his fingers all over the selection of Supreme Court Justices and re-opening the debate on a woman's right to choose, among other things. It is my belief and hope that a Liberal minority will be checked sufficiently by their low numbers in the House that there will not be a return to the scandal-plagued past. I am angry with the Liberals over the past few years of mis-management and corruption. Who loses one billion dollars? WHO? HONESTLY? What were they thinking? When these scandals were uncovered all they gave the Canadian public in response were arrogant pathetic excuses. Their belief was, "Hey who ya gonna vote for? Two right wing parties? I think not plebian. Now go out there and give me four more years." I am not forgiving nor forgetting these past few years of Liberal waste and in-fighting. In my little world I am voting Liberal to give them one last chance. I do not want someone in power that will act on an ideology that is alien to my own. The Liberals seem to be the only party that can form the government , while remaining as close to the values that I find are important to this country. God help them though if they pull their old crap again. and for god's sake, go out and vote. blargh ajc
